questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with cyclical swelling of the submandibular region post meals, accompanied by mild pain. Examination reveals an asymmetrical enlargement of the gland, and radiographs confirm a radio-opaque 3mm stone in the submandibular duct. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Submandibular gland excision): Incorrect. Gland excision is considered a last resort for stones that are not removable by less invasive methods or when the gland is non-functional.

Option B (Sialendoscopy with stone removal): Correct. Sialendoscopy is the first-line minimally invasive procedure for managing salivary gland stones. It allows direct visualization and removal of stones, particularly those <5 mm in size located in the distal duct.

Option C (External shock wave lithotripsy): Incorrect. ESWL is suitable for stones that are not easily accessible by endoscopy, especially those larger than 5-7 mm or intraparenchymal stones.

Option D (Open duct slitting): Incorrect. Open duct slitting is performed for larger stones (>5 mm) located distally in the duct or when endoscopic methods fail.

Key Points:

  • Submandibular Gland Predominance: Submandibular gland stones (85%) are more common due to the gland's alkaline and viscous saliva and the duct's ascending course.
  • Diagnostic Tools: Radiographs detect 80% of stones; CT, ultrasound, or MR sialography are used for non-opaque stones.

Management Hierarchy:

  • Small, distal stones: Sialendoscopy.
  • Larger stones (>5 mm): Duct slitting or ESWL.
  • Impacted/hilar stones: Transoral route or gland excision if other methods fail.

Tags:

Topic: Sialolithiasis, Salivary Gland Disorders

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-54, page number 836

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a bluish, soft, fluctuant swelling in the floor of the mouth. The swelling is painless but enlarges with time. Aspiration yields thick, sticky saliva. What is the most likely diagnosis and its associated clinical variant?
questions.solution:
Option A (Lymphangioma; localized variant): Incorrect. Lymphangiomas are congenital malformations of the lymphatic system. Aspiration typically does not yield thick, sticky saliva, and they do not have a bluish appearance resembling a frog's air sac.

Option B (Ranula; localized variant): Correct. Ranulas are cystic swellings in the floor of the mouth caused by the rupture of the sublingual gland duct or acini. The "localized variant" remains confined to the sublingual area.

Option C (Ranula; plunging variant): Incorrect. A plunging ranula extends through the mylohyoid muscle, presenting as a submental swelling, which is not described in this case.

Option D (Dermoid cyst; submental variant): Incorrect. Dermoid cysts are firm and not associated with thick, sticky saliva on aspiration.

Key Points:

  • Definition: Ranulas are cystic lesions of the sublingual gland, resembling a frog's air sac, hence the name "little frog".
  • Types: Localized ranula remains confined to the floor of the mouth; plunging ranula extends into the submental space.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical appearance and confirmed by aspiration yielding thick saliva.
  • Differentiation: Lymphangiomas and dermoid cysts differ in consistency, content, and anatomical presentation.

Tags:

Topic: Ranula

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-54, page number 834

choices.text: Biopsy is the first diagnostic step.
These tumors are highly malignant with frequent metastases.
The tumor arises from the external carotid artery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a slowly enlarging, pulsatile mass at the carotid bifurcation. The mass is mobile side-to-side but not up and down. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Biopsy is the first diagnostic step): Incorrect. Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected carotid body tumors (paragangliomas) as it may lead to hemorrhage or tumor seeding.

Option B (Fine-needle aspiration is contraindicated): Correct. FNA is not advised in carotid body tumors due to the risk of bleeding and tumor spillage.

Option C (These tumors are highly malignant with frequent metastases): Incorrect. Carotid body tumors are usually benign, with only a small percentage producing proven metastases.

Option D (The tumor arises from the external carotid artery): Incorrect. Carotid body tumors arise from chemoreceptor cells at the medial side of the carotid bifurcation, not the external carotid artery.

Key Points:

  • Tumor Origin: Arises from chemoreceptor cells at the carotid bifurcation.
  • Clinical Features: Painless, pulsatile mass, mobile side-to-side but not up and down.
  • Diagnostic Approach: Imaging with carotid angiogram or MRI; biopsy and FNA are contraindicated.
  • Association: Linked with SDH mutations in familial cases; may be associated with phaeochromocytomas.

Tags:

Topic: Paragangliomas

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-52, page number 809.

questions.text: During parotid surgery, which of the following landmarks is considered the most constant for identifying the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Styloid process): Incorrect. The styloid process is a landmark for the facial nerve but is not as consistent or easily identifiable during surgery.

Option B (Tragal pointer): Correct. The tragal pointer and the tympanomastoid suture are the most constant and reliable landmarks for locating the facial nerve during parotid surgery.

Option C (Retromandibular vein): Incorrect. While the retromandibular vein is a useful guide, it is not as consistent as the tragal pointer.

Option D (Posterior belly of digastric): Incorrect. The posterior belly of the digastric muscle serves as a landmark but is secondary to the tragal pointer in reliability.

Key Points:

Mnemonic: STRaP

  • S: Styloid process
  • T: Tragal pointer (most constant landmark)
  • Ra: Retromandibular vein
  • P: Posterior belly of digastric

Facial Nerve Identification: The tragal pointer and tympanomastoid suture are the most reliable surgical landmarks.

Tags:

Topic: Surgical Anatomy, Facial Nerve

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-54, page number. 846

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with varicose veins, skin pigmentation around the ankle, and a history of recurrent active venous ulcers. According to the CEAP classification, which clinical grade is assigned to this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (C4a): Incorrect. C4a corresponds to pigmentation or eczema due to venous disease, but there is no mention of ulcers in this grade.

Option B (C5): Incorrect. C5 corresponds to a healed ulcer. This patient has recurrent active ulcers.

Option C (C6): Incorrect. C6 corresponds to an active venous ulcer, but it does not account for recurrent ulcers.

Option D (C6r): Correct. C6r represents recurrent active venous ulcers, which matches this patient's presentation.

Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, Pathophysiological Classification (CEAP)

Clinical Classification:

Note: In case of multiple findings → Highest grade considered.

Etiological Classification (E):

  • Ec: Congenital.
  • Ep: Primary.
  • Es: Secondary (Post-thrombotic).
  • En: No venous etiology identified.

Anatomical Classification (A):

  • As: Superficial veins.
  • Ap: Perforator vein.
  • Ad: Deep vein.
  • An: No venous location identified.

Pathophysiological Classification (P):

  • Pr: Reflux.
  • Po: Obstruction.
  • Pro: Reflux + Obstruction.
  • Pn: No venous pathology identified.

Tags:

Topic: CEAP Classification

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 62, page number 1030.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male smoker presents with claudication and ulceration of the toes. On examination, radial and tibial artery involvement is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Atherosclerosis): Incorrect. Atherosclerosis typically affects older individuals (6th to 7th decade) and involves large to medium-sized vessels like the aorta, iliac, and femoral arteries, unlike the small vessels involved here.

Option B (Buerger's Disease): Correct. Buerger's Disease (Thromboangiitis Obliterans) is seen in young male smokers and affects small and medium-sized vessels, such as the tibial, plantar, and radial arteries. It commonly involves the lower limbs and presents with claudication, ischemia, and ulceration.

Option C (Raynaud's Disease): Incorrect. Raynaud's Disease involves episodic vasospasm of the extremities, typically triggered by cold or stress, without the ulceration or claudication described in this case.

Option D (Giant Cell Arteritis): Incorrect. Giant Cell Arteritis primarily affects older individuals and involves large vessels, such as the temporal and cranial arteries, with symptoms like headache and jaw claudication.

Key Points:

Atherosclerosis:

  • Common in older adults (6th-7th decade).
  • Involves large and medium-sized vessels (e.g., aorta, iliac, femoral arteries).

Buerger's Disease:

  • Seen in young male smokers.
  • Involves small and medium-sized vessels (Mnemonic: 'TPR' - Tibial, Plantar, Radial arteries).
  • Presents with claudication, ischemia, and ulcers.

Tags:

Topic: Peripheral Arterial Diseases

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 61, page number 1024.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic patient presents with poorly healing ulcers on the foot. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 1.3 is reported. What does this ABI value indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Normal circulation): Incorrect. ABI values between 1.0 to 1.2 are considered normal. ABI >1.2 suggests calcified vessels, not normal circulation.

Option B (Intermittent claudication): Incorrect. ABI values between 0.5 to 0.9 are indicative of intermittent claudication.

Option C (Critical limb ischemia): Incorrect. ABI values between 0.1 to 0.4 indicate critical limb ischemia due to severe peripheral arterial disease.

Option D (Calcified vessels): Correct. ABI values >1.2 suggest calcification of the vessels, commonly seen in conditions like diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease. These calcified vessels falsely elevate the ABI value.

Key Points:

Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) Ranges:

0.1 to 0.4: Critical limb ischemia.

0.5 to 0.9: Intermittent claudication.

1.0 to 1.2: Normal circulation.

>1.2: Calcified vessels (common in diabetics or patients with chronic kidney disease).

  • ABI is a non-invasive test used to diagnose peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and evaluate lower extremity circulation.

Tags:

Topic: Peripheral Vascular Diseases, ABI Interpretation

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-61, page number 1001

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of a peripheral arterial aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Option A (Iliac artery): Incorrect. The iliac artery is less commonly involved in peripheral arterial aneurysms compared to the popliteal artery.

Option B (Popliteal artery): Correct. The popliteal artery is the most common site of peripheral arterial aneurysms.

Option C (Femoral artery): Incorrect. The femoral artery is less commonly involved than the popliteal artery.

Option D (Abdominal aorta): Incorrect. Although the abdominal aorta is the most common site of aneurysms overall, it is not classified under peripheral arterial aneurysms.

Key Points:

  • Peripheral Arterial Aneurysms:
    • Most common site: Popliteal artery.
    • These aneurysms are associated with a high risk of thromboembolism rather than rupture.
  • Splanchnic (visceral) Arterial Aneurysms:
    • Most common site: Splenic artery.
  • Mycotic Aneurysms:
    • Most common site: Femoral artery > Aorta.
  • Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms:
    • Most commonly caused by atherosclerosis and the risk of rupture depends on the diameter of the aneurysm.

Tags:

  • Topic: Vascular Surgery, Aneurysms

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 61, page no: 61, page number: 1023.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm involving the descending thoracic aorta and extending to the origin of the superior mesenteric artery is classified under which type of the Modified Crawford Classification?
questions.solution:
Option A (Type I): Incorrect. Type I involves the thoracoabdominal aorta from the origin of the left subclavian artery to the suprarenal aorta.

Option B (Type II): Incorrect. Type II is the most extensive and spans from the origin of the left subclavian artery to the aortoiliac bifurcation.

Option C (Type III): Incorrect. Type III involves the descending thoracic aorta to the aortoiliac bifurcation.

Option D (Type V): Correct. Type V involves the descending thoracic aorta down to the origin of the superior mesenteric artery.

Tags:

  • Topic: Aortic Aneurysm

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-61, page number:1019

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with varicose veins is undergoing an ultrasound Doppler evaluation. The perforator located just below the knee is identified as incompetent. Which perforator is this?
questions.solution:
Option A (Cockett Perforator): Incorrect. Cockett's perforators are located over the medial calf, not just below the knee.

Option B (Boyd's Perforator): Correct. Boyd's perforator is located just below the knee and connects the superficial great saphenous vein to the deep veins.

Option C (Dodd Perforator): Incorrect. Dodd's perforator is found just above the knee.

Option D (Hunterian Perforator): Incorrect. Hunterian perforator is located at the level of the abductor canal.

Perforator Locations

Tags:

  • Topic: Varicose Veins

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 62, page number: 1026.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chest discomfort and dyspnea. Imaging reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Neurogenic tumor): Incorrect. Neurogenic tumors are commonly found in the posterior mediastinum.

Option B (Thymoma): Correct. Thymoma is the most common tumor in the anterior mediastinum and frequently associated with myasthenia gravis.

Option C (Pericardial cyst): Incorrect. Pericardial cysts are more commonly located in the middle mediastinum.

Option D (Bochdalek hernia): Incorrect. Bochdalek hernia is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia and is typically located in the posterior mediastinum.

Tags:

  • Topic: Mediastinal Tumors, Chest Radiology

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 60, page number: 992.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is categorized as a reconstructive operation for lymphedema management?
questions.solution:
Option A (Kondoleon's procedure): Incorrect. This is an excisional procedure where lymphatic tissue is removed to reduce lymphedema.

Option B (Sistrunk procedure): Incorrect. This is also an excisional procedure used primarily for thyroglossal duct cyst excision.

Option C (Neibulowitz operation): Correct. Neibulowitz operation is a reconstructive procedure involving lymphovenous anastomosis, which helps restore lymphatic drainage.

Option D (Charles' procedure): Incorrect. This is an excisional procedure involving complete removal of subcutaneous tissue and skin to manage severe lymphedema.

Tags:

  • Topic: Lymphedema Management, Reconstructive vs. Excisional Surgery
  • Difficulty Level: Moderate
  • PYQ: NEET SS

References: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st edition chapter 66, page number: 1836.

questions.text: Which of the following ulcers is typically located in the Gaiter's area, between the malleolus and calf?
questions.solution:
Option A (Neuropathic Ulcers): Incorrect. Neuropathic ulcers, commonly associated with diabetic foot, occur over pressure points such as toe joints, under the heel, and metatarsal heads.

Option B (Venous Ulcer): Correct. Venous ulcers typically occur in the Gaiter's area, which is the region between the malleolus and the calf, due to venous insufficiency.

Option C (Arterial Ulcer): Incorrect. Arterial ulcers are located at the distal ends of limbs, such as the toes, where ischemia is most prominent.

Option D (Varicose Ulcer): Incorrect. Varicose ulcers are found just above the medial malleolus, often linked to venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

Tags:

  • Topic: Ulcer Types and Locations, Venous Disease

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 62, page number: 1030.

choices.text: Non-ST elevation MI responsive to medical therapy
Mild angina with normal left ventricular function

questions.text: Which of the following is a indication for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) as per ACC/AHA guidelines?
questions.solution:
Option A (One-vessel disease with stable angina): Incorrect. Single-vessel disease without significant ischemia or symptoms is typically managed medically or with PCI if indicated, not CABG.

Option B (Left main coronary artery disease): Correct. Significant left main disease is a Class I indication for CABG due to the high risk of adverse outcomes and extensive myocardial territory at risk.

Option C (Non-ST elevation MI responsive to medical therapy): Incorrect. CABG is not indicated if ischemia is responsive to medical management. CABG is considered when ischemia is unresponsive or recurrent.

Option D (Mild angina with normal left ventricular function): Incorrect. Mild angina with preserved LV function is typically managed conservatively or with PCI if needed.

Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

  • Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA):
    • Left main disease
    • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
    • Two-vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
    • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT
  • Other indications for CABG include the following:
    • Disabling angina
    • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non-ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
    • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

Tags:

  • Topic: Coronary Artery Disease

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 59, page number: 949.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with erectile dysfunction, thigh claudication, and diminished femoral pulses. What is the most likely site of arterial obstruction?
questions.solution:
Option A (Popliteal artery): Incorrect. Popliteal artery disease typically presents with isolated calf claudication, not erectile dysfunction or thigh involvement.

Option B (Superficial femoral artery): Incorrect. Superficial femoral artery obstruction leads to thigh and calf claudication but does not affect erectile function.

Option C (Aorto-iliac artery): Correct. Aorto-iliac disease presents with buttock, thigh, and calf claudication. When erectile dysfunction is also present, it is referred to as Leriche syndrome, a classic presentation of aorto-iliac disease.

Option D (Crural arteries): Incorrect. Crural artery obstruction causes isolated calf claudication and is not associated with erectile dysfunction or thigh symptoms.

Tags:

  • Topic: Peripheral Arterial Disease

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter 61, page number: 1001.
